## Edward Bernays: Freud's Nephew and Pioneer of Public Relations

Edward Bernays was indeed Sigmund Freud's nephew - his mother Anna was Freud's sister, and his father Eli was the brother of Freud's wife Martha, making Freud his "double uncle."(no content)Born in Austria in 1891, the same year Freud published one of his earliest papers, Bernays moved with his family to the United States in the 1890s and settled in New York City in 1892.

## Key Works and Concepts

### Crystallizing Public Opinion (1923)
Reviewers praised "Crystallizing Public Opinion" (1923) as a pioneering study of the importance of public opinion.(no content)This 1923 classic set down the principles that business and government have used to influence public attitudes over the past century.

### Propaganda (1928)
His book "Propaganda" (1928) drew more criticism for its advocacy of mass manipulation.(no content)In this seminal work, Bernays argued that "The conscious and intelligent manipulation of the organized habits and opinions of the masses is an important element in democratic society."

### "Engineering of Consent"
Bernays pioneered the scientific technique of shaping and manipulating public opinion, which he famously dubbed "engineering of consent."(no content)He edited a book titled "The Engineering of Consent" (1955), with this phrase being his oft-quoted definition of public relations.

## Theoretical Foundation

Citing works of writers such as Gustave Le Bon, Wilfred Trotter, Walter Lippmann, and Sigmund Freud (his own double uncle), he described the masses as irrational and subject to herd instinct—and outlined how skilled practitioners could use crowd psychology and psychoanalysis to control them in desired ways.(no content)He used the psychological principles put forth by his uncle Sigmund Freud to promote his ideas, figuring out a way to convince the unconscious mind rather than the rational mind.

## Legacy and Influence

Often referred to as "the father of public relations," Bernays was a pioneer in the fields of propaganda and PR.(no content)Of his many books, "Crystallizing Public Opinion" (1923) and "Propaganda" (1928) gained special attention as early efforts to define and theorize the field of public relations.(no content)Bernays was named one of the 100 most influential Americans of the twentieth century by Life magazine.
